security: This file contains sensitive personal information such as names, dates of birth, places of birth, and Social Security numbers of HSCA staff and applicants. Releasing this information could lead to identity theft or other privacy violations. Additionally, the mention of a security violation case involving a CIA employee, not logged into the HSCA system, reveals a potential compromise of internal security protocols and cooperation between the HSCA and CIA. Disclosing such incidents could undermine trust and damage relationships with other agencies. Quoting directly: 'This file is of an unusual nature because it deals with an incident involving a CIA employee and this committee. It has not been logged into our system by agreement with the CIA.'
summary: This document comprises correspondence, a fingerprint analysis report, and fingerprint cards related to background checks conducted on HSCA staff and applicants, including a note about an unlogged incident involving a CIA employee.
summary_one_paragraph: This collection of documents from 1978, released under the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act, includes a report from the FBI's Latent Fingerprint Section to G. Robert Blakey of the HSCA regarding fingerprint comparisons, correspondence between the HSCA and the Attorney General concerning the return of fingerprint cards for staff, and a notice of receipt of fingerprint cards by HSCA security personnel. The file also contains a handwritten note indicating an unusual security matter involving a CIA employee that was not officially logged into the HSCA system, as well as fingerprint cards with personal information such as names, dates of birth, and places of birth for various individuals connected to the HSCA.
title: JFK Assassination System Identification Form
recipient: Mr. G. Robert Blakey, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell
